verses.text: Does not man have hard service on earth? Are his days not like those of a hired worker?
verses.comment: Job compares human life to compulsory labor, highlighting its difficulty and brevity. The word 'hard service' relates to military or hired labor, implying endurance and struggle, foreshadowing the spiritual battles discussed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Like a slave longing for the shade, or a hired worker waiting for his wages,
verses.comment: This parallels the longing for rest and reward after toil, hinting towards the hope of rest that is fulfilled in God's promises.

verses.text: So I am made to inherit months of emptiness, and nights of misery are appointed to me.
verses.comment: Job expresses the heaviness of his suffering and the sense that it has been 'appointed' for him, signaling God's sovereignty even in affliction.

verses.text: When I lie down I think, ‘When shall I arise?’ But the night drags on, and I am full of restlessness until dawn.
verses.comment: Job poignantly describes insomnia and inner distress, evoking the human longing for relief that anticipates ultimate rest, which finds fulfillment in God's grace.

verses.text: My flesh is clothed with worms and dirt; my skin hardens and breaks out afresh.
verses.comment: Job’s physical affliction is vividly described. His suffering previews the way sin marks and weakens all humanity, drawing attention to mankind's need for spiritual healing.

verses.text: My days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle and come to an end without hope.
verses.comment: The image of the weaver's shuttle shows life's fleeting nature, connecting to biblical themes of the brevity of life and man's dependence on God's mercy.

verses.text: Remember that my life is but a breath; my eye will never again see good.
verses.comment: The transience of life is emphasized. The word ‘breath’ (Hebrew ‘ruach’) echoes Genesis 2:7 and connects to the spiritual reality that life is ultimately sustained by God.

verses.text: The eye of him who sees me will see me no more; while your eyes are upon me, I shall be gone.
verses.comment: Job speaks of the finality of death, but the mention of God watching over him points to the enduring relationship between the soul and its Maker even beyond death.

verses.text: As a cloud fades and vanishes away, so he who goes down to Sheol does not come up again.
verses.comment: Sheol signifies the ancient concept of the grave. In later understanding, the hope of resurrection develops, prefiguring the promise made clear in the New Testament (2 Tim. 1:8-9).

verses.text: He will return no more to his house, nor will his place know him any longer.
verses.comment: Job laments the seeming finality of death, yet the longing for continued existence subtly anticipates the eventual revelation of eternal life.

verses.text: Therefore I will not restrain my mouth; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
verses.comment: Here Job shows the authenticity of prayer and lament expressed from the heart, connecting with the Psalms and authentic Christian spirituality.

verses.text: Am I the sea, or a sea monster, that you set a guard over me?
verses.comment: Job alludes to God’s sovereign power over chaos, linking to creation themes and ultimately to the spiritual struggle against evil.

verses.text: When I say, ‘My bed will comfort me, my couch will ease my complaint,’
verses.comment: Despite searching for comfort in sleep, Job finds none. True rest is spiritual, not only physical—foreshadowing the peace given by Christ (Matt. 11:28).

verses.text: then you scare me with dreams and terrify me with visions,
verses.comment: Even in rest, Job is troubled. God's mysterious communication can provoke awe and fear, which, as later revelation shows, precede deeper understanding and trust.

verses.text: so that I would prefer strangling and death to my bones.
verses.comment: Job's despair is deep, yet even these cries for death set the stage for the redemptive hope unveiled through suffering, a theme that recurs throughout salvation history.

verses.text: I loathe my life; I would not live forever. Leave me alone, for my days are but a breath.
verses.comment: Job’s recognition of life’s shortness points to human frailty. The desire not to continue living endlessly in suffering hints at the need for transformation through grace.

verses.text: What is man, that you make so much of him, and that you set your mind on him,
verses.comment: Job echoes Psalm 8, marveling at God’s attention to humanity. This verse foreshadows both the Incarnation and God’s intimate care for every soul.

verses.text: that you visit him every morning and test him every moment?
verses.comment: The continual presence and testing of God shows His loving providence, and these trials help cultivate virtue and spiritual growth through perseverance.

verses.text: How long will you not look away from me, nor leave me alone till I swallow my spit?
verses.comment: Job questions God's unceasing scrutiny, a frequent theme in laments. Patience in adversity and the mystery of suffering are important lessons here for the spiritual journey.

verses.text: If I have sinned, what have I done to you, O watcher of mankind? Why have you made me your target? Have I become a burden to you?
verses.comment: Job's questioning of divine justice evokes the universal struggle with sin and guilt. This anticipates the need for an intercessor or mediator—a theme fulfilled in Jesus Christ (1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: Why do you not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity? For soon I will lie in the dust; you will seek me, but I will not be.
verses.comment: Job’s plea for forgiveness points ahead to the doctrine of reconciliation and the hope of redemption offered through divine mercy, themes later made explicit by Christ’s redemptive work.
